messageBody:
Chris Eppstein wrote:

> For those of us who haven't yet embraced test first design, there is a
> common problem of making sure that our code has tests covering most of the
> code. This could mean forgetting to add a test case when a new java file is
> added, forgetting to add a test method when a new method was added, etc...
>
> Does anyone know of any utilities that can check for test coverage. This
> could be a simple as an Ant task or maybe a more complicated plug-in for
> JUnit or even a stand alone utility. Any ideas? I'd like to not re-invent
> the wheel if something like this exists already.

If your test class naming conventions mirror your class naming
conventions *strictly* (ie, Foo has TestFoo, Bar has TestBar, etc, and
Foo.bar() has TestFoo.test_bar(), etc), you can probably write some
simple unix shell scripts to look for clases and methods which are
missing tests. 'find . -name *.java | xargs grep foo' is a profoundly
useful tool. As are sort and uniq and sed and the whole maze of little
Unix shell utilities. If you aren't familiar with these tools, now's
your chance to learn! (and if you're stuck with Windows, install CygWin,
which gives you much of the command-line power of Unix).
